name: Sphinx
abilities: Petrifying Gaze: Anyone who looks directly at her face turns instantly to stone
Serpent Hair: Living, venomous snakes that writhe and strike independently
Flight: Golden wings enable swift aerial movement
description:
Explore the legendary creatures and mythical beings of this tradition.

This section is currently under development. We are working to bring you comprehensive information about
                    Greek creatures.

Check back soon for detailed entries!

<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 64 64">

weaknesses: Mirrors: Cannot see her own reflection without petrifying herself
Indirect Vision: Can be fought by reflecting her gaze or using periphery
Mortal Body: Despite her powers, her physical form can be wounded
Emotional Vulnerability: Attachment can cloud her judgment
habitat: Solitary caves and temples, places of desolation
behavior: Victim turned protector, vengeful yet sympathetic, isolation-driven

christian.overview: The Sphinx as guardian asking riddles invites comparison with biblical cherubim and Wisdom personified at the gates.

biblicalParallels.description: The living creatures with human and lion faces echo the Sphinx's hybrid form.
Cherubim guarding Eden parallel the Sphinx's threshold guardian role.
Wisdom calling at the gates parallels the Sphinx's riddle.

patristicInterpretation.summary: Church Fathers saw Egyptian hybrid symbolism as containing fragments of truth obscured by idolatry.

sources.author: Clement of Alexandria
sources.interpretation: The Sphinx's riddle about human nature finds its answer in Christ.

medievalSymbolism.bestiaryMeaning: Union of strength (lion) with wisdom (human) properly fulfilled in Christ.
medievalSymbolism.moralLesson: The riddle about human stages points to mortality and the need for faith.

christian.typologicalReading: The Sphinx's riddle finds ultimate answer in Christian anthropology: created in God's image, fallen, and restored in Christ.
scholarlyReferences: Assmann, Jan. Moses the Egyptian. Harvard University Press, 1997.
